awd_titl_txt: Evolution of Cytochrome c for Optimal Apoptotic Peroxidase Activity
awd_abstract_narration:
Programmed cell death (apoptosis) is a critical biochemical pathway that controls the growth and development of different tissues within an organism. An important early step in apoptosis is the oxidation of the mitochondrial membrane lipid, cardiolipin, by reactive oxygen species, including peroxides. This oxidation activity, which acts as an effective apoptotic on/off switch, is facilitated by the peroxidase activity of the protein cytochrome c. The intrinsic peroxidase activity of cytochrome c must be minimized so as not to accidentally trip the switch. With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Bruce E. Bowler from the University of Montana to investigate how the amino acid sequence of cytochrome c is optimized for its peroxidase function in apoptosis. This grant aims to dissect how sequence differences between yeast (no apoptotic pathway) and human (functional apoptotic pathway) cytochrome c have perfected this switch to be off when the protein is not interacting with cardiolipin and on when it interacts with cardiolipin. This project provides training for two graduate students in molecular biology methods, protein expression, biophysical methods, structural biology and single-molecule methods so that they can develop into productive scientists enabling the growth of our scientific infrastructure. The project also develops visually-exciting educational materials for a science museum in Missoula, MT that show how proteins carry out their functions, with the aim of inspiring young people to pursue careers in science.

This project uses rationally-designed variants of cytochrome c to evaluate the sequence determinants that control access to the peroxidase-competent conformer of the protein. Equilibrium and stopped-flow kinetic methods are employed to probe the structural dynamics of cytochrome c variants in the presence and the absence of cardiolipin membranes using absorbance, fluorescence and circular dichroism spectroscopies, single-molecule methods and X-ray crystallography. Peroxidase activity is evaluated in the presence and absence of cardiolipin membranes to correlate variant-dependent conformational and dynamic properties characterized spectroscopically with changes in peroxidase activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Cytochrome c is a critical protein to numerous cellular processes. It is found within mitochondria where the electron transport chain is the power plant of the cell. Cell pathways that regulate cell death (apoptosis) also flow through mitochondria. Cytochrome c is a component of both the electron transport chain and the apoptosis pathway. Thus, cytochrome c is essential for regulating key functions of the life and ultimately the death of a cell. To perform multiple functions, cytochrome c must be able to bind to multiple partners and access alternate structures.

For electron transport, the amino acid methionine at sequence position 80 (Met80) of cytochrome c must be bound to the iron atom of the heme cofactor. For apoptosis, cytochrome c uses its peroxidase activity, which requires the Met80 bond to the heme of cytochrome c to be broken, so that it can oxygenate cardiolipin, an unusual lipid found in the inner membrane of mitochondria. In this project, we studied mutations in two surface loops of cytochrome c, omega loops C and D, which are thought to control access to structures that promote the peroxidase activity of cytochrome c. Three sites in the yeast protein that are known to co-evolve were mutated to the residues found in the human protein. The peroxidase activity declined consistent with the human protein having evolved to more stringently control the peroxidase activity that helps to initiate apoptosis. These mutations did not change the stability of the omega loops significantly, indicating that relatively small structural fluctuations rather than full unfolding of these loops is sufficient for peroxidase activity. To analyze the effects of mutations on these omega loops, this project developed the EmCAST algorithm to detect unstable regions of proteins (see Image 1). EmCAST provides a general approach to rationally stabilize proteins that could have an important impact on biotechnology.

Another goal of this project was to mimic the binding of cytochrome c to cardiolipin-containing membranes in vivo. In this project, cytochrome c was trapped inside cardiolipin liposomes across a range of concentrations to measure binding to the concave inner surface of the liposome to approximate the concave curvature that cytochrome c encounters inside the cristae of mitochondria. The results showed that binding occurs at a higher lipid-to-protein ratio indicating that cytochrome c requires more space to bind on a concave surface. We also measured the binding of yeast and human cytochrome c to cardiolipin nanodiscs at the concentration of salt found inside mitochondria. These results showed that the human protein has evolved to bind more weakly to a cardiolipin membrane under these conditions. Mutagenesis studies showed that a larger set of positively-charged lysine amino acids is used to mediate this interaction than previously supposed.   

Broader Impacts: Two undergraduate and four graduate students received training in molecular biology, protein expression and purification, and the biophysical, structural biology and computational methods necessary to characterize the structural and functional properties of alternate conformers of cytochrome c. These students developed the writing and presentation skills necessary to communicate their science to the scientific community. Three of these graduate students completed PhD degrees during the project period. All three are currently pursuing postdoctoral studies. The other graduate student is still working toward her PhD. One of the undergraduate students is now pursuing a PhD at Dartmouth and the other is completing a Physician Assistant program. Six articles have been published in the peer-reviewed literature with support from this grant and several more are in preparation. Four of these publications included undergraduate co-authors. Thus, the results of this project have been broadly disseminated and have had a significant impact on human resource development in STEM fields. The project assisted in the development of a publicly available web service (www.emcast.org) that allows analysis of unstable regions of a protein and the selection of mutations that stabilize proteins. During this project, we also hosted visits from students at Big Sky High School and Sentinel High School in Missoula, who learned about the research sponsored by this grant and had an opportunity ask questions about careers in science. Aspects of this project were also incorporated into an upper division research-based Biochemistry Lab course (BCH 486) developed by the PI and offered at the University of Montana.  A Hellgate High School student also did a project that he presented at the Montana State Science Fair with support from this project.
